arm_group.description: Those patient will be given 12 hours dexamethasone after randomization
Those patient will be give 24 hours dexamethasone after randomization

brief_summary.textblock:
The investigators sought to determine whether the incidence of neonatal respiratory distress
      syndrome (RDS) in preterm fetuses is similar with 12- vs 24-hour dosing interval of
      dexamethasone.

detailed_description.textblock:
The administration of glucocorticoids to accelerate fetal lung maturity in patients with
      preterm delivery plays an important role for obstetrics and neonatal care. Many studies have
      shown that maternal administration of glucocorticoids has a significant beneficial effect in
      decreasing the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in infants delivered at
      28-34 weeks of gestation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  All patient with threatened or established preterm labor between 28 - 34 weeks
             attended to our emergency unit

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  emergent obstetric conditions like:

               -  Antepartum hemorrhage in severe attack

               -  Antepartum eclampsia

clinical_study.official_title: Dexamethasone Dosing Interval: 12 or 24 Hours Apart? A Randomized,Clinical Trial

other_outcome.description: Determine whether the incidence of admission to Neonatal intensive care  is similar with 12- vs 24-hour dosing interval of dexamethasone.

primary_outcome.description: determine whether the incidence of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is similar with 12- vs 24-hour dosing interval of dexamethasone.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Determine whether the incidence of perinatal mortality is similar with 12- vs 24-hour dosing interval of dexamethasone.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Prevention
